Incorporated welcome to the black hat briefings 1999 this meeting was held in exciting Las Vegas Nevada from July 7th
through the 8th this is videotape number 25 track B towards a taxonomy of network
security testing
techniques I've been ask to remind you that this talk is being recorded um our friendly cameraman back
there um I want to say be before I really get started that this is a work in progress It's not this is the way it
ought to be this is the way we should discuss it it's an attempt to provide some language and some structure so that
we can talk about vulnerability scanning Tools in a better way um so I encourage
you to give me feedback either in questions or afterwards about how to do this stuff
better oh oops the
speed there we go so I'm I'm going to talk a little bit about um who this talk
is intended for um some of the goals of the work what what taxonomies are and why why
they're useful why I'm doing this um and then talk about the the two big classes
of testing that the way I think about them which are exploit testing and inference
methodologies uh so the main the main audience of this talk the reason I think many of you are here is because you use
security scanners and you're frustrated by them because work the way you would expect them to work
um you'll expect it to exploit a problem and it goes off and does something else
and then says you have a high risk vulnerability here which is not the case and I'm going to try and
explain what the thought processes are um at a vulnerability scanning shop that
lead us to do these things um I'll say that I work for NCH now bind view we
make the hacker Shield vulnerability scanner this is what I spend most of my time on is these issues and how to best
test for security problems in a real world environment and what what the
constraints are and I think that once you understand what the issues that we Face are and how we build the tools it's
possible for you to be more effective in using them in your job um knowing what
you're doing and what the tool is doing makes it possible to use it better and
also unlike the virus world or unlike the firewalls world all of the vulnerability scanner groups are working
in their own little company you have a couple of smart people they get together
they write a scanner occasionally at conferences like this one we talk over beer but we never really have serious
engineering discussions about what we're doing or why and I think that holds back the field as a whole it makes it less
less likely that improvements in one scanner will get into others it makes it less likely that the tools will be
successful and used so I want to talk to people who are doing this work
um so how do scanners find vulnerabilities what are the constraints
why do we use these bizarre inference methods why why don't we always just do exploit testing and actually go in and
see if the vulnerability is really there um and lastly I want to say that Greg
hogland will be talking at 4:00 today on why scanners suck it should be a very good talk um and I'm not going to focus
on a lot of that stuff because he seems to have covered it well so I'm just going to explain to you how we do these
things um so taxonomies are this is a taxonomy talk and we're
using a taxonomy because taxonomies are useful intellectual tools when you put things into categories and those
categories work you can talk about them in useful ways we can talk about what a script Kitty can do to your your system
we can talk about what a professional cryptographer can do we can talk about what organized crime or national
security interests can do and that's a taxonomy it's a way of classifying
things together so that we can call them a class we don't have to talk about individual
instances um so good taxonomies have have strong
differentiations between them um the periodic table of elements is a type of
taxonomy and has these great distinctions everything is in a box and those boxes are based essentially on
electron shells and the Order of things and the position lets you infer all sorts of things about the
elements um a bad taxonomy doesn't have very clear borders very clear
distinctions but it's worth noting that even a good taxonomy that works really well for a lot of things has problematic
items in it and the duck build platypus is an example the duck build platypus is a mammal all mammals give birth to their
young live and they they suckle them well the duck build platypus is a mammal
that lays eggs um in every other way it's a mammal it happens to lay eggs but
biologists put it in as a mammal so sometimes taxonomies have these have
these sort of Border issues so to talk about how these things
actually work there's there's two ways that most people will expect something will work
one is exploit testing um you actually run the exploit see what the result is
and life is good you know what the answer is with a good degree of reliability or so you would expect the
other is Banner checking um Satan did a lot of banner checking when it came out it works almost entirely on banners in
fact and a lot of people um have said it's not a good scanner for that reason
and I disagree and I'll go through why as I go through the talk um phf is a
classic example of an easy exploit test to do there you have an exploit you feed that to Port 80 on a web server you look
at the result you decide if it's a password file or not and you decide what the result is it's reliable it's mostly
non-intrusive it doesn't leave core files on the system it doesn't crash anything it
doesn't um it doesn't leave a big gaping hole on the system that wasn't there
before and it's intuitively correct you look at a scanner doing that and you say yeah
that's what the scanner ought to have done um and that's that's a challenging thing
because we want scanners to work this way and there are good reasons which why
they do not always do it um so Satan as I said uses banners it looks
at for example a mail banner and says well gosh that's s mail 4.1 it has
this set of vulnerabilities I'll report that it has all of these vulnerabilities um it's less intrusive
that's a really easy Banner to change in fact I changed my banner which I pulled off the system to from ready for mail to
ready for exploit and change the date on it um this is remarkably unintrusive
there's no difference between a banner check and someone's starting to send a mail
message um so the the effect on the system that you're looking at is very
low but a lot of people will worry that this is not a good method because it
it's an easy to change banner it's not exploiting the problem so is this correct is this acceptable and I'm going
to come to why the scanners will in fact use this sort of method um so I want to
talk about terminology and before I dig into the actual terms I want to say that
all of the language used in vulnerability scanners vulnerability problem risk test check is
overloaded um these words have lots of meanings and if I spoke Greek or Latin well I might have used Latin words but I
don't so I'm going to ask that you accept that I'm using common words in
ways that have fairly precise meanings and these are meanings that we have evolved at an attack and at bind
view um in years of daily usage these are the ways that we have agreed to use the
terms between us because having precise definitions helps I'll also say that
this terminology is not standard across vendors um if you go to ISS or network
Associates or web Trends or one of the other scanner vendors they will use different words to mean the same things
and this is one of those things that I'd like to start to change I'd like people to start to use the same terms CU When
we use the same words to mean the same things we can communicate better so um a
vulnerability we use in in a non precise sense
um it's a design flaw it's a defect it's a misconfiguration it's a bad password it's anything somebody can take
advantage of um and if you talk to academics about what a vulnerability is
um there's some great work that was done at Coast in really defining exactly what
a vulnerability was and what you should and shouldn't call a vulnerability and
we've chosen not to use those definitions um because it doesn't work
from the point of view of building and writing a scanner um so problem is a synonym for
vulnerability and rather than use vulnerability because it is such a loaded word we often say we're looking
for a problem um or we're looking for a vulnerability why are we confident that
the system has this vulnerability um we use test to mean an
actual test an exploit or other thing which takes advantage of the problem and
says you have this problem in a way that is a
test um we use inference for any methodology that doesn't actually
involve testing for the problem but inferring that it's present so the banner methods are all inference methods
any way anytime we check a version we check a registry key that's an inference we don't see the vulnerability we see
something which leads us to believe that the vulnerability is there so in the sen mail Banner thing we would infer that
sen mail has the debug problem on this system
um so in exploiting a problem um again we have the the phf exploit up here
because it's an easy one um we we actually think about this in terms of disproving a hypothesis we will
hypothesize that the system is safe we will run a test we will find evidence
that our hypothesis is wrong and um report that back to the
user um one thing that happens in in a lot of exploit tests is that you
don't actually see the result so quickly the phf is a little unusual in that we
see the result in the same TCP connection that we made and on the next slide I'll
explain um that there's problems like major Dom reply to where you set up a
mail connection you send major Domo message that has a um bunch of shell Escapes in the reply to field and it
will execute commands for you that's really Nifty but you cannot see the results of the check in the same TCP
connection so there's issues of timing there's issues of did some other thing
that happened on the system while we were checking it while we were testing it excuse me cause this result for
example if you ping the host um that you're checking from you know you've got your Target and you send back a ping in
your reply to well maybe maybe somebody else pinged your machine for some reason or maybe there's a hold up in the mail
queue um you know the spool disc is full and you won't see that ping 4 16
hours um so there there are multiple types of
exploits and as you get into actually looking at the exploits you see that many of them you can't actually directly
see the results and that leads to a loss of reliability and a loss of
Effectiveness in doing a test um so I talked I talked briefly
about um hypothesis tools will both assume that there's
safety and assume that there's risk and both of these are legitimate effective
methods but intuitively there's an assumption on the
part of a tool user that the tool is assuming that their safety and going out and finding evidence of risk you expect
when you see your tool come back and say You're vulnerable to this that the tool has gone out and found evidence that
that is the case um there are times
when the impact of a test is substantial enough that it makes more sense to look
for evidence to infer that the vulnerability is there or not there um
and assume risk and try and disprove that for example if there's no male server on the system you can reasonably
well infer that the system is not vulnerable to a major do or reply to bug and in that case what we're doing is
we're really assuming that there is a risk and finding evidence that there that that risk does not exist um and
this this often surprises people when they first encounter it a lot of people um especially the kind of people we hire
to join our security team argue with this um quite extensively because it's intuitively wrong you really want to be
able to say yes we found evidence that are that this isn't safe you don't want
to do that but we've come to a conclusion that we're comfortable with
um that assuming risk and looking for evidence it's not there is an effective and valid technique
um yeah so often times when when doing an exploit test people people will want
to look at banners and looking at banners is an interesting thing in exploit tests because it really boils
down to um are cheating and not accepting a strict definition of
vulnerability at the bottom of the page here we've got two different definitions of a vulnerability one is a web server gives
out Source when percent 20 is appended to the URL and the other definition of a
vulnerability is the IIs web server gives out Source when percent 20 is appended to the URL it's not clear which
is the right definition of the vulnerability which is the right definition of the vulnerability actually
has an effect on how you test because if the right definition is IIs has this
vulnerability then you need to check that I is the web server in question and you won't see the
vulnerability on another system um whether or not to do this
is really boils down to an academic discussion of what a vulnerability is
and how to define it and you'll see even within tools um inconsistencies about
what they do because it's not a settled argument and as tool users you need to
understand that this sort of thing may happen from time to time as a vendor we' like to give you better information
about what we're doing and why the tests come out the way they do
um so one one benefit of doing
this doing these Banner tests and why we do them in various exploits is because
you reduce the the impact of a test by only testing on a system you expect is
going to be vulnerable um
if another web server little web server that you've never heard of crashes when
given that percent 20 you're going to get a call from an angry customer whose web server you just crashed um because
you were doing this this vulnerability check which you thought was a legitimate thing which wouldn't crash anything um
and so sometimes you'll insert banners to reduce the denial of service effects of tests um
it astounds me even being a very cynical person with a very dim view of software
quality it astounds me how many things crash in bizarre ways when you run a
security scanner against them um an X terminal that will crash when
you connect to its SNMP port with an empty request um HP printers will go
down when you port scan them um the TCP stack just can't handle rapid successive
requests to different ports um so what what a vulnerability scanner
does when it runs tests is it's trying to violate the security of the system we are trying to do things that the
implementers of the code didn't expect would happen and you know that often
causes weird things to happen um you can leave core files you can fill logs um
some exploit tests I've seen will add rud to accounts um which is one of those things that you as a customer probably
really don't want to have happen to your system as we're running a test um it'll make copies um if we need
to read a file we need to read Etsy Shadow to demonstrate that a test actually works then all of the sudden
we've got a copy of etsy Shadow on our host it we may delete it immediately but
parts of it may end up on the swap file or in other places and that's a violation of your system security you
don't want us to copy that data off of your system because you'd like it to stay secure you'd like it to stay on
that machine but at the same time to do the intuitively correct thing
and test for the vulnerability we have to go and get that file we have to be sure that that file is present that we
can read it that we can analyze it and so this this conflict this tension is is
one of the things that leads us to use inference testing methods or excuse me
inference checking methods um because people come to us and complain
gosh this vulnerability scan crashed this service it left my machine in this funny state I'm not happy make it
less make it less impactful on the network make it less aggressive and
so um with even talking about how to test for denial of service problems like teardrop and
land U we we're we're going to come to using inference methods um because people ask
that we Nosh engage in this destructive behavior on their
networks um and that's legitimate you want to be able to test your network without spending a week cleaning up
after yourself um denial of service testing is fun with with demons
there's there's sort of two ways you can do it there's the connect attack and then reconnect and if you reconnect it
it's not vulnerable method um it doesn't work if your system is under inetd and
denial of services against inet D spawn things are fun because you can often absorb memory create core files uh stop
the service for a little while um and it may also fail because of other reasons
uh we we've seen firewalls that have some intrusion detection stop this sort of thing we've seen machines crash in
between the time that we do our service denial of service check and try and reconnect the host will crash for some
other reason um the reconnect fails and you believe there's risk when there's
not um so a lot of these checks will um look very carefully at the way a
connection ends um the the semantics of TCP when you crash a service are very
inter interesting and very dependent on how the service is running what sort of
watch dogging there is uh and we've had customers ask well how can you know that this service is down you didn't bother
to reconnect this is how um we watch the connection very carefully we look at the TCP flags and a reset plus push almost
always means that we crashed your service and something above it um is giving us a response inetd is letting us
know that the connection is no longer there um whereas a fin will usually mean that
service is just shutting us down um yeah the the some demons die on
connect clothes strobe found a bunch nmap found a bunch um just running through a machine
you discover running through a machine twice you'll discover you get different results um services will die off when
you're doing this port scan um and the other thing the other thing that makes denial of service testing very difficult
is systems often fail for reasons unrelated to the particular test that you're doing at the time um and you'd
think well you know you're doing a scan it takes a few minutes to a few hours
How likely is it that a system will die well when you deploy lots of vulnerability scanners against lots of
systems you end up finding lots of situations um where a system fails for
reasons completely unrelated um but you get blamed for for it uh was that a production server oops
we really try to avoid this we we try really hard it absorbs a lot of time and energy um but it happens and it it
happens because we're doing things that the software doesn't expect um sometimes
it happens for reasons wholly unrelated we had uh an interesting one recently
where somebody scanned about two dozen machines and mostly NT machines in the
morning three of them were hung and called up to yell at us and we asked well how many of your NT machines
usually hang over a given night and the answer was well one or two and the person wanted to blame us
for all three being down until they really thought about what the reliability of their Network and services was um so we come to less
intrusive methods um and there's two two large types of less intrusive methods
and those are the inference methods which I've talked about a little bit and credentialed methods and I'm going to go
through the inference methods that we use as and then talk a little bit about
credentials um so if the exploit will crash the target if the output can't be
reliably parsed this is actually an interesting challenge there are some really simple
Services which vendors love to muck with finger is was the first example that
really struck me if you try and finger a user at a given host on um a dozen
unix's you'll get back between a dozen and 18 different response formats which
you need to parse reliably um in order to say that finger is turned on and not
just producing a banner which says we have no information about this user or we've turned finger off um and then you
hit your 14th version of Unix and the check no longer works so that is an example of a place which
most of us have probably encountered where actually writing a reliable parser to declare that this
thing is doing something that is obvious to a human Observer is a little on the
difficult side um exploits are still secret there's a lot of exploits which
are discovered by companies and then not disclosed that not only means that you
can't get them to play with it it can mean that we can't get them to play with it um there are a number of scanner
companies which publish exploits very regularly without the details and then
do not share those details so in those cases people need to
use inference methods they need to use methods other than an exploit because the exploit is not
available um exploits can violate the rules I've done penetration testing work where
we were not allowed to actually exploit any problems we had to say what can you
see when you go and look at the system without exploiting anything well you end
up doing a lot of inference work then another thing about inference
methods is that the distinctions here are more clearcut than they are in the exploit methods and that comes from the
fact that here we're doing things of our own design to infer that the problem exists or does
not exist in exploit methods you're forced
to do something that approximates an exploit and exploits are messy they're written in a lot of different ways the
way they actually function varies immensely and it's hard to put lines
between the various exploits and say we divide them this way and this way with inference methods because we're in more
control and the things we're doing are more classifiable we have more clear-cut
distinctions um versioning versioning is sort of a super set of banners it is you
ask the program what version it is it gives you an answer you make a decision based on that answer it is really
actually very effective when the banner information is hard to change to change the banner information in name d you
need to go in and edit the source same thing with SSH send is a different story you know if you can
uh just go in and understand a send mail CF file which is a little difficult um
you can change the banner um and I just wanted to point out
here that usually what will happen is we'll use a banner matches some regular
expression and the version is less than n and this generates a set of false
positive results where we'll see a version which is so old that
we don't actually know if it's vulnerable we'll declare it vulnerable you ought to update it
um and people will complain you know oh that vulnerability was introduced in version three and we're running version
four so it's got other vulnerabilities but not this one um not having access to version
three not wanting to check every back version that might exist generally the way the logic Works inside the scanning
programs and and here I can say this is not just ours this is all of them because we've done competitive analyses
to see how they work um almost everybody uses a banner matching and version less
than method in doing some of their version checking um Port status
checking um there may be a you the way this works is you try and connect to a port and then you declare that there's a
risk there sometimes the risk is that there's something listening on the port you know
if your policy is we only allow SSH into this machine and there's another Port
open then the fact that the port is open is a risk um you can also use this when additional
probing is not likely to reveal any more information um there's a lot of RPC
programs mounty being one of them that has a couple of buffer overflows and we can crash mounty for you that's that's
pretty trivial to do um but we can only really do that once and we don't learn a lot because
most versions of mounty can be crashed with similar exploits so if we see an
RPC mounty listening we may declare risk because anything going beyond that is
simply too intrusive um and this sort of checking gets really
interesting when you're trying to do it through a firewall when you're trying to do it with UD UDP you send off a UDP
packet nothing comes back well do you get a port unreachable that was swallowed by the network was there
something there and a lot of times you'll end up sending multiple
packets to try and get a response from one of them now this becomes difficult
when for example your SNMP demon dies when it gets an empty trap um so there's there's this tension
which constantly exists between doing a lightweight test and doing a
very reliable test and the effect of testing on a system which is not robust
your system shouldn't crash when I do this but if it does then not only did I
mess up your system a little bit but I give you bad results so I one of the things that I'd
like you to take away is an understanding of that tension and that difficulty which people making
vulnerability scanners are dealing with um protocol compliance as a means of
finding risk um you exercise the server a little bit more than Port status um it becomes
a little bit more intrusive a little bit more reliable um you declare vulnerability
based on the results if your policy is no web servers then it's very effective
to get index.html and then declare risk this this is a valid way to do a test
and if there are services that you don't need running a lot of the checks will simply say oh yep this looks like an
echo service you ought to turn it off um Behavior gets a little bit more
complicated and a lot of times it tends to blur into exploit testing what you do
here is you examine the edges of the protocol to see what the implementation of the software is for example qmail
when you connect to it has a distinctive help message which tells you about qmail um whatever you'd like to do to
the banner that qmail produces it's unlikely that you're going to go in and change the help file so we
use the help command to get more information um qmail also has some
distinctive error messaging that it uses um various web various other mail
servers will Implement verify and turn and esmtp with different responses and
you can learn a lot about the family of software that's running by exploring
this sort of thing um and if you can demonstrate that the software that you're examining Works
differently than the software that you know has a risk or a vulnerability in it then this is a reliable way to say this
software does not have this vulnerability because to produce this set of behavior that we have in front of
us would require that the user go in and modify a bunch of things which generally are seen as not mattering and ignore the
vulnerability in his system so we consider Behavior to be a reliable way of
working um credentials are a level up credentials are at the same level as
testing and influence methods and it's a generic way of talking about logging
into the system before making your determinations um unix's login password
NT account names password and log logging in on NT for for those of us who
who come from a Unix background is a little weird you send the credentials as part of various API calls and the server
evaluates them um credential checking doesn't include public SNMP traps that
are public are not really credential they're public Anonymous guest accounts we don't class as credential
checks um credential checking is very non-intrusive except when you install
when you install you need to collect up these credentials you need to install software on the machine um and that's that's a royal
pain it's really very reliable stuff though if you can log into the machine
as root if you can connect as administrator you can learn everything about the
system and go into lookup tables and say this is configured wrong which leads
to this vulnerability that's configured wrong leads to this vulnerability um and there's a bunch of
ways to do that you can ask for software in version information you can md5 files
and then compare to lists of known good or known bad um You can call various apis to
gather data um PS netstat um some various SMB things on the NT side and
you learn an awful lot awfully quickly and most scanners will try and do some
things with credentials from time to time um so um in conclusion I've tried to um go
over the techniques that we use based on exploit techniques based on inference
techniques based on credential techniques so that you have a high level understanding of how these tools work um
why they work the way they do um which which is often hard to understand until
you've been through it a lot um I've tried to go over some of the pros and cons of the various
techniques and explain why we do them the way we do them and again this this
is a work in progress where I believe there's a lot of interesting work left to be done um scanners are not the
greatest tools in the world today and I think understanding these techniques
talking about how they work and why they work um how to enhance reliability
without enhancing the intrusive is something that I hope will come as people think about these in more
rigorous ways than they have so are there any
